entry.title: Combined summary - Blocksize and off-chain transactions
entry.summary: The debate on whether to increase the blocksize limit to accommodate increased transaction volume in Bitcoin remains ongoing. Some argue for off-chain transactions, while others support raising the limit. However, it is recognized that big businesses will likely push for a higher blocksize limit within two years. Still, limiting the blockchain to single-digit transactions-per-second is not an option, and off-chain transactions will also be necessary for instantly confirmed transactions. There have been discussions about dropping support for old nodes without proper discussion, which goes against how Bitcoin works and may cause significant disruptions if that version were to become obsolete. Several proposed solutions have arisen in response to these issues. Pieter Wuille suggested a "considerate mining" setup where pools run on either the newest or second newest version, but connect to the rest of the network only through a node of the other version. Once the majority has upgraded to the newest version, the proposal suggests dropping the older version and introducing a new one instead.Michael Gronager clarified that the issues were in version 0.7 and below, not in 0.8. He argued that changing features in 0.8 to accommodate the previous versions was not a good solution, as it would not cover similar situations in the future. Instead, a hard fork is required to change this behavior, but dropping support for old nodes without discussion is not reasonable. The way forward is to get a 0.8.1 version that mimics the old behavior while fixing the lock limit issue.Consensus is key in making decisions that affect the entire Bitcoin ecosystem. A hardfork may be necessary at some point, but it needs to be carefully considered to prevent disruption to the network. In response to the controversy over increasing blocksize, Gavin Andresen argues that raising the block size limit is necessary to scale up the blockchain but acknowledges the need for off-chain transactions for "instantly confirmed" transactions. The discussion is tabled until version 0.8.1 is released.The Bitcoin protocol has faced issues in the past, particularly with versions 0.7 and earlier. Pieter Wuille proposed a solution to address the issue of version 0.7 getting stuck by releasing version 0.8.1, which would mimic the old behavior as a stopgap measure. Nonetheless, it was suggested that the new version should not emulate the old behavior too precisely, as it may cause issues for nodes using version 0.7. Instead, a network with a mix of version 0.8.1 and version 0.7 nodes would remove the risk of a fork. In an email exchange between Pieter Wuille and other members of the Bitcoin community, the topic of dropping support for old nodes was discussed. It was deemed unreasonable to put the majority of the network on a fork without discussion. A hard fork to drop the 0.8.1 limit requires widespread community consensus, not just from miners and developers. The decision to ensure all nodes can accept mined blocks is important for the stability of the system, but dropping support for older nodes without discussion goes against how Bitcoin works.Finally, it was suggested that there would unlikely be multiple forks of any consequence in permanent coexistence and that a successful competitor to Bitcoin would have to arise as a fork of the UTXOs in the block chain. Decentralization offers no benefit to big businesses, making them a regulation target by virtue of size alone. It is crucial for developers and users alike to understand and follow the protocol to maintain the integrity and stability of the Bitcoin network.
